147241894.review:
This game is what you make of it. I have a pretty high tolerance for jank/bugs but I've considered dropping Kenshi multiple times for the sheer frequency of characters bugging out and getting stuck in walls. The game is also very unbalanced and several systems appear to be semi-broken or pointless. At the same time, the variety of environments and the extremely interesting world kept me coming back. Even though some parts of it don't make sense, this is very different from other "management" games I've played like Dwarf Fortress, Rimworld, etc. Overall Kenshi is like the Alpha version of the greatest RPG ever made. It's inconsistent, buggy, frustrating, and extremely interesting.

Edit:
After my characters became stuck in a wall for the 500th time and I had to recall everyone back to my base I decided to change my review to a not recommend. There's a lot to love here but the lack of polish is so extreme that it just is not worth fighting the game to see what it has to offer. It's really disappointing because I really enjoyed parts of my experience, but the game is just borderline broken. 

There really is a fantastic game under all this mess but it is just so clunky that 2/3 of game time will be spent wrestling with poorly designed mechanics, engaging in tedious micromanagement (For your own sake use the bed healing speed up mod), or finding workarounds to bugs. I really wish the game would get out of its own way and let me explore this weird and fascinating setting. I hope that someday this game reaches its potential but it seems like the developer is already working on a prequel/sequel so its unlikely.

The reason for not recommending this game is the fact that the game is held together by paperclips and duct tape. Not my words but I agree and like how it rolls out.

I do not want to criticize Chris too much since he did not have a $220m budget. I do give him credit for hard work and good effort, 10/10. 

I do not approve of the decision that has been made, unpopular opinion, of dropping this game to work on Kenshi 2 rather than finishing (improving) this game and porting it to another engine. 

I feel like the gaming industry nowadays trends in unfinished, unpolished games and always move on to the next new project which gives you that spark and excitement. I just hope that LoFi/ Chris doesn't follow that same pattern because despite how good Kenshi really is, bugs and glitches have ruined countless of my games and the experience just isn't smooth enough for me to recommend it to someone else.

EDIT: I am editing this review so that my review doesn't off-throw anyone from trying the game. Because in all honesty; it is a great game and if you don't try this you'll miss out on an innovative master piece (IMO).I paid $20 and still have fun (mostly) playing 12 hours a day without pulling my hair out knowing that the company had a $220M budget and brought out such oversold overhyped bulls***, TODD.

I have clocked in 880 hours in the first 3 months I played it and another 300 in the past month after I took a break from it (gonna be more). Unlike modern games this game actually has replay value because you can do everything different without the game breaking (probably not breaking because there are bugs, there are mods that fix some things in the workshop.)

My first review spoke truth and I still think Chris should have ported the game, improved it and made it better by adding all the things that he initially wanted (engine restrictions for some things, PORT IT ALREADY).

Which brings me to my next point. This game was made by 1 sole developer (at first) whom in my opinion put his heart and soul into a game where more just isn't possible because the engine struggles.   Unlike people saying Bethesdas games can't handle stuff because "engine issues". I wanted to make that comparison real quick to express how truly amazing this game is. Bethesda can't even pull something like this out of their arse with a $220m budget and a team of 500 people because they are too busy focusing on making money, bringing up the hype, marketing stupid watches which nobody gives a F*** about except a few hardcore no expectation fan boys who will gobble up any s*** that is fed to them. Verbally speaking, not literally. OH AND A HEADSET OMFG NEVER SEEN ONE OF THOSE BEFORE TODD.

Big gaming companies lack passion and innovation for games because the people in charge are afraid of taking risks so they stick to the same boring formula, except that if you spend $200 more you get a watch. So congratulations TODD.

This game was made through passion/innovation is all i'm trying to say in many words and many examples. Despite the duct tape analogy and the many other issues that it does in fact have.. Recognise specilisation, who tf. It's like they replaced all the words which are supposed to have Z's in them with S's and reverse vice versa...

Obviously this type of game isn't made for everyone; ezpecially the grammar police. 

The learning curve is steep and to truly have the Kenshi experience I feel that the player needs the knowledge to fully play this sandbox game how they see fit. With that being said, the learning curve is extremely fun but also infuriating at times.

P.S Dear Chris,

No offense but I just cannot recommend this game. Your baby, Kenshi, is abandoned and so many mechanics just feel unfinished and deep down I know that more was planned (some of these listed down below I found on your old forum but others, I as the player can tell are unfinished considering the creativity that went into this game and then there being parts that just feel slapped on top so that it works). If only you ported that what was already there and completed the mechanics that were left in the dust. E.G) Assassination, enemies can't break free, the player can't break free (when being carried). Why do the mercenary A.I s just run away from their squad when they had enough of fighting and just stand glitching in the middle of the town/cities without repercussions from the captains. Where are the thievez, the azzazzinz that should come after the player. Skeleton eyes that the player can equip when his eyes get shot with a bolt, WHERE ARE THE CHILDREN AND MY HEIR!? Anyway, I can go on but I wont.

All in all 10/10 game just sad to see it's been left in the dust.

146622380.review:
For starters, this game is riddled with bugs - many of which are game-breaking in vanilla state and can be incredibly frustrating (albeit circumvented through Shift+F11 tools, but take away from the immersion and intended playthrough). Outpost building is subpar when building on diverse terrain and topology (which makes up most of the Kenshi map), even compared to games like Age of Empires. Pathing is abysmal and requires meticulous intent compounded on by the frustrating micromanagement required once your party size grows.

The remarkable thing, however, is how amazing this game is and what potential it has/had. The game was made by one person over the span of ~5 years, but has since been able to garner a handful of dedicated developers. 

There aren't really any meaningful developments/patches/updates/hot-fixes being made as I presume headcount and manpower is being placed on Kenshi 2, which is in development and set to be GA sometime soon (optimistically Q4 2023 or realistically sometime in 2024), while leveraging Unreal Engine.

The workshop is lacking as far as 'quality of life' content goes, through no fault of the community or modders, but purely from modding tools and access to certain content.

That said, it's single-handedly the best buggy game I've ever played. Where the game excels in is with its story-telling, true RPG nature, and openness that allows you to get to "end-game" loot, events, and areas straight from the beginning. You really can do whatever you want (within the limitations of the actual game itself).

Is it worth $30? In my opinion, no, but given the pure passion and dedication that went into realizing its existence, which is outright admirable, one could make the case. The bugs are too apparent and game-altering to validate the claim in my arguments, however, and so I would not pay the full retail price tag on it. 

I got this game for $8, but I would've settled for ~$15-20 given its current state.

In the meantime, I'll be actively anticipating Kenshi 2.

146616100.review:
Unlike so many other tittles that boast that "You can make your own story." Kenshi does not rely on you to pick up the slack and fill in the void left by devs never implrementing features and mechanics for you to actually make your own story.

Kenshi is a brutal, open world, squad management, base building, farming, action roleplaying game where you are plopped out into a world that does not care if you live or die. You are vulnerable, alone and confused as you take your first steps out into wilderness that WILL kill you.

It is a harsh teacher that expect nothing more than patience and creativity from you as it sets you up for failure that you will learn from.

One of the best games on Steam.

Buy it.

47h in a bit more than 1 week. What can I say... I have no life a part since I got that game.

But been honest: do not come to this game expecting something that is not. It is an RPG, but not the common one, because you are not the main character. You are not more important than a NPC. Therefore, there is no guide, no history. You create yourself. If you are into it, buy it. If not... Not your game.

Also, it has an important strategy/management component. Hence, if you are like me, someone who loves strategy games (Paradox, Total War, AoE, etc.), or management games (i.e., Going Medieval, Sims, etc.), I believe you can also LOVE IT!

PS. It can be easily modded, which for most is positive. You can find a lot of things in the Workshop or Nexus.

146507581.review:
Second run after getting beaten, arrested and dying on attempting to escape from prison in the first run:
> Start in crappy run down town
> Mine copper for profit
> Decide I will be a miner and sell my ores for profit
> Farm copper and iron
> Make fat stacks
> Hire companion to bodyguard and help mine copper
> Make tons of money
> Decide to buy cow to help carry more copper
> Search in a wasteland for an hour to find someone who sells a cow
> Finally find farmstead in a holy land and buy a cow
> On the way back to my mining camp
> Like 8 bandits sprinting at me on the horizon
> Realize cow is high value target
> Send cow to run away
> Prepare my men to fight
> Accidentally select cow when pressing attack
> Almost scream out loud, scared of losing my nine thousand dollar investment 
> Cow immediately plows through like 4 bandits, tearing off a leg and an arm and leaving a massive pool of blood
> Other guys fight off bandits as cow absolutely destroys the bandits trying to escape
> Cow is insane
> Travel with band of mercenaries and nomads until we reach some town
> Pack of wolves attacks and breaks one of my guys legs
> Guards come from town, a few die to the wolves
> Try to take opportunity to get some sweet guard armor
> Immediately get caught because guy I tried to loot was bleeding out not dead
> Guards attack stealing guy, broken leg guy tries to attack guards and defend teammate, immediately gets rocked
> Both in jail
> Broken leg is super good at lock picking and stealing guy has super high athleticism meaning he can run super fast
> Broken leg unlocks cage and breaks fast guy out
> Fast guy sprints out screaming obscenities, bringing the cow with him
> All guards in town immediately go after him
> Broken leg guy slips out of cage during all the commotion
> Regroup and head back to camp to lay low
> Finally make it back to mining camp
> Start mining
> Group of bandits sneak up and knock my guys out, breaking another leg on the same guy as before in the process
> Bandits immediately devour cow 
> Slavers pull up to see my guys bleeding out on the street with a half eaten cow
> Slavers pick up guy with no broken bones and start to pick up guy with broken leg
> Pack of wolves come out of nowhere and attack slavers
> Slavers barely survive and leave, forgetting my guy with a broken bone on the ground
> Broken bone guy stops playing dead and slowly crawls to nearby town
> Broken bone guy starts healing while enslaved guy plots escape
> While travelling to camp slavers get distracted by giant ostrich beast
> Sprint away with my enslaved athletics 40 guy who runs at 20km/h
> Regroup and lay low until slavers stop looking for escaped slave
> Have existential crisis after realizing all the ore farming I was doing was essentially the same as what they would have me do as a slave
> Cope by rescuing random slave girl who wants to be a fighter
> Train her up by having her carry backpacks of iron
> Adopt a dog while this is going on
> Decide to check out new spot on the map with newfound family
> Find cool robot explorer
> Travel around for a while living with no cash because mining is for nerds
> Group of slavers pull up
> Battle goes on for about thirty IRL minutes as I'm pausing and trying to figure out how I can win
> Barely survive with beaten and dying men and dying robot
> One survives, heals others
> Goes to heal robot, realizes he doesnt have a repair kit
> Repair kits cost like 5000 dollars
> Do not have that kind of cash (around 1000)
> Realize what I must do
> Frantically mine copper with all three of my guys as soon as they recover while the dog guards the dying robot
> Make barely enough
> Buy repair kit
> Sprint to repair robot
> Robot is seriously dying
> Finally get there and start repairing
> The damage is too great, robot dies in the arms of my family of misfits
> Jaw drops to the floor

All of this happened in about 13 hours of gameplay, with no story, no quests, just me playing, with my own goals, in a massive world, meeting random characters. I should say that this game is an amalgam of things I dislike: I don't like slower stat based rpgs, I don't like real time strategy, I don't like survival games, and I find apocalypse games such as fallout to have extremely drab and ugly environments. Yet despite being all these things and more rolled into a giant meat taco, kenshi has me utterly captivated in its gameplay. Everything happens in a fairly non scripted open world/sandbox environment where a lot of the fun is simply experiencing and living in the world. 

No game has ever had me so connected to my character (And ironically, there is no given story to your character) as the only way for your character to improve in something is to experience it for themselves, want to get better at fighting? Go fight then. Want to get tougher? Get beat up more and survive. Want to do anything? Keep failing until you get it right. Whatever doesn't kill you will make you stronger and that is how you progress in this game, the high difficulty comes not from the actual enemies in the world (though they are quite tough) but instead knowing what fights you can and cannot take, all of those stat points mean nothing if your character is dead in the wasteland, and this raw feeling of survival gives you such a will to live and a want to grow to be the strongest, no other game has ever come as close to the feeling of intensity for me as kenshi has. 

Steam says I've only played about 13 hours of this game so far but those 13 hours were so special I felt the uncontrollable urge to post a review. While reading the reviews for this game I was highly skeptical of the freedom it claimed to have as I am used to having controlled freedom such as in a bethesda or rockstar open world game; in games like that there is a huge, lush open world to explore but the story or side quests are only happening in one little dot on the map. This is not that, this is a true open world experience with unbridled freedom where you make your own story, interactions and personal experiences. Not that there is no dialogue, there is some written for interactions in towns that are often deadbeat ironic statements that I find extremely hilarious, and depending on the race/gender of characters in your party they have special things to say to each other about places they visit and things they do in passing that can be an informative or comedic reprieve from the desolate and violent wasteland that surrounds them. 

Despite the world of kenshi being very run down and barren from an outside view, the game still feels full of life and action, even though all that surrounds you is an ancient, utterly destroyed world. While I dislike drab environments with little in them where simply walking around makes me want to throw up, kenshis world is so captivating and deeply atmospheric that I've actually come to like the visuals for the most part. About 99% of the music is also amazing. There is one track (Or maybe its some sort of sound effect) that I find incredibly irritating and loud, but other than that outlier; the simple, haunting melodies which sound like exploring a ghost town perfectly match the atmosphere of wandering and surviving a wasteland alien world. I've only spent a few hours in the world of kenshi so far, but its left more of an impression on me than most games I've put a hundred hours into have. I look forward to exploring more of this world in its vastness; until then, see you space cowboy.

Edit: I've played 30 more hours since this review, my opinion has not changed on this game overall, but there is so much more I could say as I've gotten into it. I would buy this game again on a different account just to review it again

146354817.review:
Kenshi is tough to learn, but once you get it figured out, it's incredibly rewarding. It doesn't hold your hand, you're not special and you'll probably lose a few characters before you get yourself into the groove. 
If you like a challenge, this game is worth checking out. It is a grind, that is certain, but as someone who doesn't generally like grindy games, this one actually struck home for me, for some reason. It feels rewarding, watching a character's stat increase by even a single point, especially with how easily that character could be maimed, slaughtered, cannibalized or forcefully amputated. By the time I had my first proper base established, I was feeling pretty high up, my squad even defended their home from one of the big factions that we upset, with aid from the allies we'd made. 
Yet, Kenshi didn't let me ride the high for very long, and soon it humbled me by cutting off my main man's left arm, to remind me of my place in the natural order. BUT, now he sports a mechanical prosthetic in its place, and it's made him even more dangerous than before, despite being one of the lower end arms. 
Make the best out of a bad situation, failure is only failure if you crumble to it. 
Highly recommend to anyone who enjoys games like Darkest Dungeon or Dark Souls (no, I am not calling this a "Souls-Like") who take joy in overcoming difficult odds.

Love games like this, unique, different, very hard...
Hard to leave review for a game you cant really compare to any other game.
Game feels like it's set in post apocalyptic desert environment like mad max but with Japanese feel and stile.
You fight with hand weapons only (maces, cantatas, swords, bows, shields ...)  and your actions improve your skill that you are using, there is no levelling. 
Example: running while carrying heavy load improves your strength, fighting with cantatas improves your cantata fighting skill ect...
You have to play for a bit to learn which enemies are weaker and which one you should run from. There is no easy way of knowing who should you fight and who not to.
You can lose your limbs and get robotic new ones. You can be enslaved or have bounty on your head, you can also play it as a strategy building game and control your new built settlement. 
Also I love the fact that game was made by one person over period of 6 years :-O\
Definitely game to recommend...

146084531.review:
I don't really make reviews very often. But, I have played this over the years and I always come back to it. While there isn't much direct story, and mostly in the background for the setting, learning as you go. The game may have a high learning curve, with a somewhat janky UI and learning can be a brutal process, potentially frustrating if you are not invested enough to put the effort in. I do recommend any new player put themselves in the proper mindset to push through that part.

However, throughout that process, I discovered one of my favorite games of all time. Kenshi is a game that can be enjoyed in elaborately different ways.

-Do you want to play a single-character focused RPG? 
-Do you want to play a settlement simulator similar to Rimworld? 
-Do you want to play a real-time CRPG focusing on a single party/squad?
-Do you want to play a squad management focused game, managing resources and different objectives you create for yourself?

All of these things in this glorious sandbox, are various ways you can enjoy and play the game. To make the story yourself and play it in anyway you want. Not to mention, the elaborate Mod Community. A personal favorite of mine is the Star Wars conversion mod. 

Please give this game a chance, and you'll enjoy an incredible experience unique to this game.

146079369.review:
Kenshi is a game about great contradictions. On surface, Kenshi seems to check off everything a bad game has: bad graphics, shoddy optimization, confusing lore, and grindy gameplay. But at it's core, it embodies what a good game or piece of media should be. It follows the most basic yet important of story-telling: show, not tell, and it achieves a level of depth in gameplay seldom seen before in any other video game with astonishingly simple mechanics. Good games focus on being a master of one instead of jack of all trades, but the greatest games are able to be the master of all trades. Kenshi is one of these.

Roguelike, RTS, RPG, Sandbox, Squad-Based Combat, Post-Apocalyptic Survival, City Builder. Never has a game been so numerous and diverse in it's genre. You can play as a merchant, a lone wandering swordsman, a farmer, or an outlaw. You can forge factions and empires of your own, or you could destroy the ones already in place. No playthrough of Kenshi is ever the same, and even with more than the 1,000 hours I put into the game, I still discover new thing about the game day by day, despite the map of the game being a mere fraction compared to other games with the same amount of depth. The game has little to no audio, yet it has some of the most illustrative and emotional OSTs I've listened to. It has graphics that are decades old, and yet it possesses scenery so unique and beautiful you'd hang them up on your wall like some kind of avant-garde painting. The combat is simple, you click on an enemy and order your character to attack. But despite such simplicity, I watch each battle with bated breath and suspense.

Kenshi is a byproduct of a much simpler and greater era of video games. Developed by one man over the span of 12 years, it contains the passion, energy, and soul of the games from 2006. It came from a time where success was achieved through honest hard work and relentless drive, a far cry from today where games are mass-produced and sterilized for pure profit. It's one of the few games I would genuinely define as art. Art is one's ability to put their emotions and abilities onto a medium, and the game's developer Chris Hunt did exactly that. 

Reading about the game's development, you hear of the many challenges and limitations Hunt had to face, such as the constant toiling at a security job to secure enough funding to just develop the game part time. At times it would seem that the future is bleak and not worth the effort, but Hunt pulled through, and created the masterpiece we have now. This is mirrored in the game. The game's world seemed so harsh and full of suffering, and the player would face constant challenges and limitations. But by getting up every time and never losing hope, they eventually achieve great success.

As the first ever review I made for a video game with earnest, I rate Kenshi a 10/10.

145980043.review:
Good game, but the building interface wants to make me kill myself.
Examples:
#1: You build two building sites close to each other, [this is natural as one area might have something the other lacks,] The two then join and suddenly you are closer to a town so you can no longer build on one of the sites.
#2: Workers won't use stuff automatically from animal backpacks.
#3: Walls built on hilly terrain often split so you can't walk on them, and you have to spend a literal half hour to hour just making the game work as it should from the get-go fixing the walls. [If you can't walk on walls you can't man crossbows, which are literally the only counter you have against the huge bandit waves that pop up from day 1 and attack your settlement].
#4 Can't build stuff too close to eachother. If you could build ramps more freely it would be fine for the aforementioned as you could just patch up the symptom instead of addressing the problem, but even the tiniest clip will prevent you from placing things.

Don't get me wrong, it's a great game but I will change my review to positive when the game improves the building system so it doesn't literally give me depression. This whole game is about dealing with setbacks and improving on them but I can't  deal with the trash bugs and flaws in the building system on top of that.
If you decide to build in this game, I recommend you only pick a site with everything you need close together [good luck finding that lol] And on completely flat ground. Note that you will likely never find an aforementioned site as stated previously that would circumvent some of the pain I feel with this game.
Also a brightness setting would be good as it's hard to see at night if you have windows open.

Edit: I got a jester emoji for pointing out the bad building interface? I mean, if you like spending 2 hours trying to fix walls more power to you. Go build a base on hilly terrain and you will see what I mean. Or was it for my window comment? Lol

145919205.review:
An excellent sandbox RPG with a post-post-post-apocalyptic atmosphere. A living, expansive, dynamic, beautiful and brutal world keeps gameplay fresh with plenty of replay value. While Kenshi has some obvious limitations the variety of stories which can be told within this framework is just amazing! I've played a righteous Crusader of the Holy Nation; a band of would-be freedom fighters desperately looking for a way to bring down the racist bigots of the Holy Nation; a lone martial artist experiencing his personal evolution while fighting slavers; a no-hive intent on carving a safe haven for other Hivers with no home... Every time I enter Kenshi's world there are new characters, challenges and adventures just waiting around the corner! Graphics are good, though maybe a little dated, and the sound direction really adds to the dangerous atmosphere of the world: sombre silence interspersed with exotic and varied musical pieces.

As mentioned, there are some limitations to the game: The UI and navigation can feel a little clunky at first. Moreover endgame content seems a little spartan after a few playthroughs. Good news is that if vanilla content is not enough for you there is a very active modding community offering a smorgasbord of mods ranging from quality-of-life updates to new areas, quests, characters and whatever else you may be looking for.

My time in Kenshi's deserts and desolate places has been truly breathtaking and addictive so far and I can't encourage you enough to make your own way into this unforgiving world.

145821134.review: Kenshi is an incredible storytelling game with a lot of depth. This is an unforgiving world, where you can just as easily lose fights as win them and end up with limbs chopped off or being eaten alive. The graphics aren't great, controls take a little getting used to, and there is a bit of a grind, but despite those drawbacks the game is still incredibly fun. With an incredible amount of lore and a variety of play styles (you can build a base and sell drugs, or adventure and sell slaves, or raise an army and attack entire kingdoms), Kenshi is definitely worth the price.

Overall this is a great game. The sandbox style allows you to do anything, or attempt anything at least with death being the most likely result. At first this game had me feeling very lost and confused, but as I experimented in the world I find out how everything works and it all become easy. 

Pros:
-The AI felt so realistic with how they interact with you when first encountered, their prompts are hilarious to see. I still like them a lot. 
-Lore and how it fits into the gameplay is nice.
-Skeletons

Cons:
-Loading world chunks is frequent and annoying, thankfully the loading is not slow.
-Graphics/graphical glitches, this stuff could be better but obviously it is an old game. With that being said you will run into areas where the camera isn't working properly and you need to constantly maneuver it to see what is going on.

But it's one of the coolest, most original universes and concepts to come out for a while. I guess it's a grim-dark Western with a lot of culture imported from feudal Japan. There's crossbows and katanas; you can earn your money as a trader, a bounty hunter, or maybe stick to mining, farming and retail of the weapons you smiths have crafted. It is fair to say that you should def subscribe to a couple of quality-of-life mods available in the workshop but there's dozens you'll want to play with after learning that the vanilla experience kinda demands every good fighter to have been pummelled into the dust, on the verge of death, dozens of times. Strong modding community, and kenshi 2 is officially in the works  - I specifically bought a PC in anticipation of it!

An awesome game, will keep you grinding and learning about the world for a long time as you slowly get stronger and stronger, becoming more confident leaving home, venturing further and further until you finally meet your end. Has a lot of freedom to play, no missions, no invincible characters, no one telling you what to do, unless you want them to that is. Be everything to the owner of a town or a slave too weak to escape it's captors. 

Mods truly make this game shine, giving it so much more life and content, and I think the mods heavily influenced my enjoyment of the game. Also, not hard to mod yourself if you want specific starts or to make special characters or even take exiting ones in the game and edit them, even making them recruitable. 

All in all a great game if you are willing to learn it and take the time to sink into the world, and start your own story.

145557303.review:
Kenshi es, sin lugar a dudas, uno de los videojuegos de sandbox y RPG más ambiciosos y cautivadores que han salido al mercado en la última década. Su mundo abierto post-apocalíptico, desolado y vasto, invita a los jugadores a sumergirse en un entorno donde la supervivencia es clave, y cada elección tiene un peso y consecuencia.

Una de las características más destacables de Kenshi es la libertad que otorga al jugador. No hay un guión estricto que seguir ni misiones lineales; eres tú contra el mundo, y cómo enfrentes sus desafíos depende enteramente de tus decisiones. ¿Quieres ser un comerciante nómada? ¿Un bandido? ¿Quizás liderar una ciudad o convertirte en un cazador de recompensas? En Kenshi, todo es posible.

La mecánica de construcción y gestión es particularmente impresionante. Los jugadores pueden construir sus propias bases, gestionar recursos, y enfrentarse a las amenazas de facciones rivales y criaturas del desierto. Esto aporta un nivel estratégico y profundo al juego, donde la planificación y anticipación son esenciales para la supervivencia y el éxito.

Gráficamente, aunque Kenshi no compite con los triple A más pulidos en detalles, tiene un estilo distintivo que se adapta perfectamente a su ambiente post-apocalíptico. Las vastas llanuras, montañas rocosas y desiertos dan una sensación genuina de un mundo desolado. Además, su banda sonora es sutil pero inmersiva, llevándonos a través de las desafiantes tierras con una mezcla de melancolía y tensión.

Quizás lo más atractivo de Kenshi es su dificultad. No es un juego para aquellos que buscan un paseo tranquilo. Es brutal, implacable y a veces frustrante, pero eso es precisamente lo que lo hace tan gratificante. Cuando logras avanzar, cuando superas los desafíos, sientes un genuino sentido de logro que pocos juegos pueden igualar.

En resumen, Kenshi es una joya en el mundo de los videojuegos de sandbox y RPG. Su profunda mecánica, su mundo vasto y desolado, y la libertad que otorga al jugador, lo convierten en una experiencia única y obligatoria para aquellos que buscan un reto y una aventura auténtica. Es una prueba de resistencia, ingenio y estrategia que te mantendrá enganchado durante horas y horas.

145480814.review:
Don't get the hype behind this game. Tried to force myself to like it, can't break into it. 

- I was expecting a thrilling experience judging from the reviews and what do I get? Whacked around wherever I go.
Just a lazy way of telling you "the game is hardcore"

- The lore in the game? Yeah, it's not as interesting as people portray it to be ... I can tolerate mundane lore but kenshi in my eyes seems to lack any depth to it. Once again, don't get the hype.

- User interface/Controls or Learning the game? I swear I had an easier time learning Everquest project 1999 as a newbie.

- The world environment? Vast emptiness that's got nothing interesting to offer other than a load of mobs/factions trying to maul you. (Except the swamps, the swamps were cool to discover so thumbs up to that)

- Quests? Pffft yeah, virtually none existent in my short time of playing this game.

- Combat is trash. Simply put trash. I understand the aspect of trying to portray your character as being worth nothing and be an absolute good for nothing nobody but at least give me a fair chance of deciding my own worth in combat for god's sake. (Out come the fan boys telling me that if I micro manage my positioning and my block/attack ratio about 1000 times per each combat session + grind my combat/toughness skill I'll be able to take on an entire squad of 16 people or some sh*t)

- The grind. I've played enough RPGs/MMOs/Survival games, can we please stop normalizing grinding in games? This is yet another piss poor excuse of prolonging 'gameplay'. There is nothing fun/engaging about it and usually the satisfaction time you get out of it is minimal at best.

- Graphics? I personally do like them, just a shame that there is very little sight seeing in game to enjoy them. (Unless as previously mentioned, you're in the swamps)

I get it. It's a sandbox game. There is not meant to be any goal within the game other than to 'survive' really but at least make the game SOMEWHAT interesting other than throwing in cannibals and skin stealers to entertain the empty void that this game provides. (HURR DURR DURR MODS)

TLDR; Severely disappointed, would not recommend to anyone unless they're big into games like HOI IV or CK III/Europa Universalis and that's a big stretch in itself I believe. Tried to force myself to play it and it ain't clicking chief.

This game hates you and it's beautiful.  Not graphically, no, but in its desire to make you suffer.  And suffer you will for the first 10+  hrs, too broke to get ahead; starting over and over again because you lost an arm or a leg or something to the first dog you attacked outside of the town you spawn in and bled out dragging yourself on bloody leg stumps somewhere in the desert.  Perhaps finally 3-4 hrs in you almost have a base built but get beaten unconcious by a group of starving, rag-wearing hobos because you are weak af and can't fight for shit because of your missing arm from the dog earlier.  You think "I Almost had enough for that cybernetic arm too" as a slaver comes along and grabs you up to sell into bondage which ironically would heal you and feed you,  but you bleed out and die on the way to their hideout anyways.  Add the clunky game mechanics and its incredibly frustrating at first.  But, then the mods come, and that takes this game to a whole new level of customization and enjoyment.  Lightsabers or marvel characters, mods that could make you into a 500 stat 'roided out toon so muscular and huge how could it possibly even wipe, much less swing a sword and run 26 mph?  Super fun game to play, if the frustration doesn't make you rage quit first, you will probably drop 200+ hrs in it easily.   Easily.  Look at workshop mod collections first before downloading random ones here and there and getting a bunch of conflicts.  A few needed are only on nexus or the like.

Start with RE_Kinshi as its kinda the base mod the others may need.

10/10. Game of the year. Unrivalled.

First ever character; I ventured out into the vast desert only to run into the arms of slave traders who captured me along with a group of bandits. 
However, we were held up by a major dust bandit camp along the way; I watched my enslavers engage in bloody combat until the man who had carried me fell, and I was flung just far enough across the sand that I was left alone to slowly recover as my fellow slaves were brutally murdered by the bandits.
I ended up regaining consciousness, unlocked my shackles and limped back to the hub - only to be finished off by yet another group of bandits halfway there.

I have never felt this thrill before. The limitless possibilities! I've only been at it for a few hours and burned through way too many characters in that time, but it already feels like a game I could play for every free second of the rest of my life.

144950590.review:
Kenshi is a true gem in the world of gaming. With its vast open world, intricate mechanics, and endless possibilities, it's a title that deserves every bit of its 5-star rating.

From the moment I stepped foot into the harsh landscapes of Kenshi, I was utterly captivated. The depth of the world-building is simply astounding. Whether you're a lone wanderer or a leader of a thriving faction, the immersive storytelling keeps you engaged at every turn.

One of the most remarkable aspects is the freedom of choice. You're not tied to a linear narrative; instead, you forge your own path. Want to be a wandering trader? Or perhaps a fearsome warrior? The game accommodates every playstyle seamlessly. The intricacies of the economy, survival mechanics, and base building offer a level of depth that's both rewarding and challenging.

The characters you encounter are richly detailed, each with their own motivations and stories. Whether it's forming alliances, recruiting companions, or facing off against foes, every interaction feels authentic and meaningful.

Graphically, Kenshi's distinct art style paints a post-apocalyptic world that's both bleak and beautiful. The attention to detail in every nook and cranny speaks volumes about the dedication of the developers.

While Kenshi's learning curve can be steep, the journey is undeniably worth it. The sense of accomplishment as you overcome hurdles and grow stronger is unmatched.

In conclusion, Kenshi is a masterpiece that offers an unparalleled sandbox experience. It's a world where you're not just playing a game, but creating your own saga. If you're seeking a truly immersive, challenging, and endlessly enjoyable adventure, Kenshi is the game you've been waiting for.

144608426.review:
Kenshi is a game that I originally thought "I would not like this game. I am not really a fan of RTS games.". However, after talking about the game for so long with a close friend of mine, I decided "Heck it, I'll give it a try.". Little did I know how quickly this game will challenge me. Being dropped into the middle of nowhere. Choosing what is considered the worst race to start with (Not knowing that at the time). Feeling completely helpless and lost in the already intimidating and desolate landscape right smack dab in the middle between the United Cities and Holy Nation warring area. Needless to say, yikes!

In my honest opinion, it took me quite a bit of time to get adjusted to how this game played. It is unforgiving, relentless and punishing for anyone new to the game. Having to be very careful with your fragile character(s). Stealthing around, gauging your attacks and knowing when to flee (or play dead, if unfortunate to run away and you miraculously survive). This game single-handedly gave me an amazing experience that I am pleasantly surprised to have. It has a lot of depth, working mechanical parts. Everything feels like it has meaning. The landscape, the combat, the interactions — pretty much *everything*. This game has a lot of downtime and you will park your rear just healing a lot of time until you become more familiar with the land, more geared up, more experienced and tougher. Oddly enough, it's not discouraging. If anything, it encouraged me more to press forward in this "survival of the fittest" landscape that also has some of the most dangerous endemic life or even simply the people who run any town(s). 

I really can not express the level of detail this game has. It has really become one of my favorite games. It is very odd considering it is an RTS but hey, when a game is good, a game is good. I really hope when Kenshi 2 comes out, it is just as engaging and enjoyable as this is and I look forward to what Lo-Fi Games comes up with.

144394797.review:
So after 19 hours in I can safely say, this game is absolutely amazing! 

NOW ALL NEW PLAYERS, 
I want you to know that at 19 hours played i'm still new, to explain further. 

At 19 hours I just:
1. Expanded my crew to 7, it was at 5 and it was kinda rough some days cus food was hard to come by. Making it to a city and then earning cash to make food was sometimes a chore; its like real work, but its so rewarding.
2. Finally found a secure way to make a good source of money, all I'll say is that it revolves around mining and an efficient way to do it. I don't want to spoil it to much cus honestly it was the most rewarding feeling ever to fiqure that out.
3. Started winning fights vs the bottom of the barrel gangs, aka the hungry bandits. I will say, the learning curve is massive, i'm still learning and I feel so achieved just where i'm at now figuring out a strategy to handle big fights with my 7 guys. Skill is everything, numbers isn't. THOUGH that doesn't mean go fight some massive gang cus sometimes them numbers get real lucky, but you want less people at first so they can actually level up.(and you can afford to feed them)

That's all ill say for now, but the game is definitely worth it at full price; this is the most fun i've had with a single player game in a long time if i'm quite honest!

144234606.review:
Kenshi has undoubtedly secured its place as one of the most exceptional open-world games to grace the gaming realm. With its sprawling landscapes, deep gameplay mechanics, and unparalleled freedom, it's a must-play for anyone even remotely intrigued by the sandbox genre.

From the very first moment, Kenshi draws you into its enigmatic world, where you're left to forge your destiny amidst a vast and unforgiving landscape. The beauty lies in its versatility – whether you aspire to be a nomadic trader, a formidable warrior, or a resourceful survivor, Kenshi grants you the canvas to paint your own story.

Embracing a harsh realism, Kenshi offers a survival experience that's both demanding and gratifying. Your choices have consequences that extend far beyond the surface, shaping not only your journey but also the very fabric of the world around you. With every challenge overcome and every milestone reached, you'll find yourself more engrossed in the intricate tapestry of this captivating realm.

The game's dynamic world is a marvel in itself. Factions vie for power, towns rise and fall, and opportunities materialize in unexpected places. The level of detail woven into this ever-evolving universe is astonishing, creating an immersive environment that invites you to explore every nook and cranny. Each encounter with diverse NPCs and hidden wonders adds to the sense of wonderment that Kenshi effortlessly delivers.

While not aiming for cutting-edge graphical prowess, Kenshi's distinctive art style is a testament to its unique charm. The audio design complements the atmosphere seamlessly, further enhancing your connection with the game's world.

Kenshi's learning curve may prove steep, but the satisfaction derived from mastering its intricacies is beyond compare. The game's vibrant modding community infuses it with endless possibilities, extending its longevity and ensuring that each playthrough offers a new adventure.

In summation, Kenshi stands tall as a remarkable achievement in the open-world genre, inviting players to lose themselves in a realm of boundless opportunities. With its expansive landscapes, immersive gameplay, and addictive mechanics, it's a game that deserves a spot in every adventurous gamer's library. Embark on your journey through Kenshi and unveil the myriad tales that await – it's an odyssey you won't want to miss!

If I had known that this game was a Mod-fest I wouldn't have gotten it. I don't know why I got hyped up by all the reviews. "Guys you can sell slaves! Guys you can be a slave! Guys! Slaves!"

I've been murdered in the desert by the first random thing I came across several times. I haven't even had the opportunity to extort another human being for fun and profit. It's just been pure death. My death.
So I read more about the game. "Install mods!" they all tell me. "Mod's make the game amazing!"
But wait I thought this game was supposed to be this amazing immersive sandbox all on it's own?

When I first started playing this game, I was confused as to what was there to do. No quests, no storyline, no anything. So I decided to look up on forums and the answer I found was usually the same: "Just do whatever you want, you can be and do anything."
Well, for a game where you supposedly are allowed to do anything you want, I found that you can't actually do much. The gameplay loop is mostly the same. > Begin my adventure as a lone flatskin wanderer, nothing but a steel club in hand and a cloth around my waist.
> I scavenge around the town for things to sell. Find nothing but a few worthless jugs which fetch me a few monies.
> Venturing outside, I find a few copper deposits. I decide to mine and sell as much as I can so I can afford food.
> Manage to make enough money to buy a good load of food rations. I  go to the tavern outside of town to trade the fruits of my labour when it is suddenly ransacked by a group of bandits. They mercilessly slaughter the shopkeep and his guards. I managed to make it out in time but they gash up my leg. It's a good thing I bought a first-aid kit.
> Continue to mine every day to earn as much money as I can. After I've bought up a good portion of food, I set out for Squin, a Shek settlement a few miles away. As I approach the gate, I come across the rotting corpse of a starved bandit, his hand reaching towards the gate in desparation. Poor devil. Feeling a bit guilty, but in need of good clothes to protect me from the elements, I take his shirt and pants. He won't be needing them anyway.
> On my way towards Squin, I am harrassed by more bandits who knick me in the head with a bolt, but I manage to outrun them and make it into town. The guards slaughter the bastards. I patch up my head and make my way to a nearby Inn to rest up.
> I proceed to live the life of a simple 49'er, mining copper deposits and selling the ores to merchants. On my first excursion, I got so caught up in my work that a gang of bandits jumped me and took all of my rations. I manage to bandage myself up but all the food I worked so hard to buy was now gone. I've been far more cautious since then.
> I eventually make the acquaintance of a young Shek named Ruka at the local pub. She was once a proud warrior, but her horns were cut off as punishment for faultering in battle. She was now nothing more than a servant. We quickly became friends and she agreed to stick by my side.
> After a little more copper mining, I'm able to save up enough money to buy me some new clothes, a sturdy pair of boots, and a decent sword.  I also hire another Shek companion, a female by the name of Meow. As part of her induction, I clip her horns and name our squad "The Short Horn Hoodlums".
> I decide to take a break from mining and explore the surrounding areas with my posse. After some travelling, we come across the reeking Swamps south of Squin. We venture into the swamps to see if there is anything of value.
> During our expedition, we are ambushed by a gang of swamp bandits. My companions and I are ill-equipped to fend them off and are gravely injured. We are left in the moor to bleed to death.
> My corpse is later devoured by the local wildlife. The remains of my two companions quickly decompose, claimed by the treacherous swamp.

143955924.review:
This game is some kind of bizarre mad max flavored crack. That's the only explanation I have for it. 

There's a lot working against this game. I bought it well over a decade ago, wrote it off, only to find out the madman making it had worked on it for the entire time it took me to graduate college, work in my industry, realize I hate it, and go back to school, and finally they released it in 2018. It's full of jank, built on ancient technology and after all that development time pieces still feel like they are obviously missing. It refuses to explain itself beyond the bare essentials and does not respect your time. It's incredibly easy to make a decision that will take you hours to implement and then hours more to realize has doomed you. It's simultaneously punishingly difficult and incredibly exploitable if you are so disposed. It's unapologetically dark and full of cannibals, slavery, drugs, and murder. It's a workshop heavy game, with all the stress that comes with that. It is NOT for everyone. 

But dagnabbit if you are the type of person to persist past all of that does this game suck you in. It has the open world and oblique world building of an elder scrolls game combined with a degree of freedom and self-determination that I can't think of seeing anywhere else. It feels like a fully realized world that is having a conversation with you. It tells you you are weak by throwing hordes of starving bandits at you who pummel you into the ground but the very act of standing up again makes your people stronger. It tells you that you are inconsequential, sends taxmen to shake you down, runs you out of town, until one day you come back trained and armed and kill the leader of a faction and throw the entire world into chaos. It smites you with acid rain and orbital lasers and raids by bloodthirsty slavers even as you slowly build up a city of your own construction into one that rivals any of the established communities on the continent. It has crab tournaments!

I have simultaneously loved and hated this game at times, but I haven't been able to get it out of my head, and probably won't until I have asserted my dominance over this weird, slow, complicated game world. I sit at work thinking about my little team and what on earth I should do with them. Are they strong enough to make a pilgrimage north to defend some depressed fisherman from their resigned fate slowly being whittled down by the privations of cannibals? Should I send them into the fog to cut their teeth fighting endless masses of crazed queen-less insectoid cults? If I set up a base are they strong enough to defend it? Where would I even want to settle? What is my 10 step plan to getting strong enough to overthrow Holy Lord Phoenix and his racist misogynist army of zealot slavers? AND HOW DO I BEAT THE CRABS?

I appreciate that this game exists and I think it stands alone and unique, such as it is. It is a flawed masterpiece. Look before you buy to make sure it's the kind of thing you'll be into. 

Finally, long live Beep.

Are you fucking serious? You're actually thinking about diving headfirst into the festering cesspool that goes by the name of Kenshi? Well, grab your shit snorkel, because you're about to drown in a tsunami of unadulterated frustration and misery.

Imagine this: you fork over your hard-earned cash for what's touted as an "open-world RPG masterpiece." But what you end up with is a colossal dumpster fire of broken mechanics, half-baked ideas, and enough bugs to rival a termite infestation. Congrats, you've just been royally fucked over by Kenshi.

Oh, and let's chat about combat, shall we? Get ready to witness your so-called skilled warriors flailing around like stupid morons in the middle of battles. Bandits? They'll make mincemeat out of you. Wild animals? They'll maul you into submission before you can even say "Why the fuck am I playing this?"

But oh, the pièce de résistance: the AI. Your party members will showcase a level of idiocy that defies the laws of nature. They'll charge headfirst into danger, get stuck in the most fucking ridiculous places, and come up with innovative ways to off themselves, all while you're left swearing up a storm and contemplating launching your computer out the fucking window.

And don't think for a fucking second that the world of Kenshi is any better. It's like traversing through a shit wasteland of monotony, where the highlight of your day is probably counting the grains of sand that make up the shitty desert.

But wait, there's more! Brace yourself for crashes and bugs that could only be the result of a %@&@ developer's twisted sense of humor. You'll be lucky if you can go  minutes without the game crashing and shattering whatever thread of sanity you had left.

So, go ahead, be my fucking guest. Dive headlong into the abyss that is Kenshi. Bask in the glory of its broken dreams, its shattered promises, and its relentless assault on your patience. But don't come crying to me when you're left huddled in a corner, foaming at the mouth, and fervently wishing you could fucking erase this fucking travesty of a game from your memory.

143784907.review:
I'll be honest it took me several tries to get into this game. It can have a slightly steep learning curve if you just try to figure it out for yourself. However, I was always drawn back to it's bleak, lonely, dystopian atmosphere, and now I have to say this is one of my all time favorite games to play. Mods keep it continually interesting, and if you enjoy a challenge, this game is for you. It can feel very, very, very difficult at first while later on you may find yourself to be a complete bad-ass, but there always seems to be someone, or something out there, whether it be new NPCs or factions or simply bad situations you can get yourself into to keep the thrill of being alive... well alive! After multiple play throughs, I have to say the journey from weakling to formidable influencer is extremely rewarding. Best part is, even after you have been established you can continue to recruit weaklings and start the cycle over again of leveling up characters if that's what you enjoy doing.

In my opinion this game is fairly unique in it's styling. I've seen people describe it as simply a base building game. It does have that aspect, but that is only one. You can choose to play it however you want. Whether it be more a role play style or base / army and faction building. You can choose to be good, or bad, or both (I mean in reality isn't good and bad really full of mostly grey areas). It's basically a shite world, and you start with basically nothing, and try to make a go of it. You can even choose to start with a big fat smelly shite sandwich if you want to make it extra fun. If you don't know what to do when you start, you'll likely get a beating and stain the sand with your blood as you slowly lose your last breath with a mouth full of dirt. Then you can start again and try not to do they same dumb thing you did last time. Maybe one day you'll rule the world of Kenshi.

143762355.review:
Gather 'round you wretched wasteland wanderers, and let me spin you a twisted tale of a game they call "Kenshi." A swirling vortex of chaos and survival, Picture this: a desolate landscape, a mishmash of post-apocalyptic nightmares, where bloodthirsty bandits and mechanical monstrosities roam with a sense of purpose that's more deranged than a paranoid junkie on a bender.

The controls? Well, they're as clunky as a broken-down dune buggy held together with duct tape and dreams. In this world, where every decision might land you in a cannibal's cauldron, elegance isn't the name of the game. But mark my words, dear readers, for all its grotesque charm, Kenshi possesses an addictive quality that's akin to the grip of a savage hallucination. You'll curse its name as you fumble through its intricacies, and yet you'll find yourself drawn to it like a moth to a bugzapper.

In the end, "Kenshi" is not a game for the faint of heart or the stable of mind. It's a wild ride through the savage landscapes of the digital abyss, a fever dream that blurs the lines between reality and the deranged fantasies of a chemically-altered psyche. Approach with caution, for once you enter this realm, you can quit, uninstall and walk away but you can never be done with it.

143761810.review:
Aun recuerdo como tuve mi primer acercamiento al juego, considerando que su gameplay es un poco tosco fue bastante caótica la partida, entendamos que el juego al empezar te da una serie de ventanas con información a forma de guía o tutorial pero en muy poco tiempo esta se torna agobiante y es muy fácil pasar de esta, puede que esto sea un problema a la hora de conservar el interés del jugador, pero eso no significa que el juego sea "difícil" de jugar, pues a pesar de todo la  jugabilidad es intuitiva y desde un primer momento logra atraparte, la posibilidad de elegir tu inicio en este mundo y no exactamente tus estadísticas o tus roles lo considero un total acierto, es increible el como con tan solo unos minutos jugando mis personajes ya estaban teniendo mini-historias cada uno a pesar de estar en el mismo lugar y grupo, dando la sensación de que mi partida tiene vida propia y que cada personaje tiene carácter de personalidad distinto, da pie a la construcción de narrativa como nunca antes había experimentado, me vi a mi mismo dando roles como el chico malo del grupo o el pacifico a diferentes personajes tan solo por los eventos que habían llegado a suceder alrededor de ellos.

Fue solo a unas horas de juego que encontré uno de los mayores fallos y es que a veces el juego peca de una optimización lenta y que aunque teniendo en cuenta que es un sandbox totalmente abierto y con mil mecánicas sucediendo al tiempo había momentos donde sentía que viajar entre zonas era agotador por la cantidad de tiempo que tomaba el cargar el mapa, pero aun asi es algo fácilmente pasable pues entre zona y zona fácilmente puedes pasar horas explorando (o intentando huir de gente que te captura).

Su apartado de gestión de ciudad y construcción de esta misma es muy satisfactoria, puedes fácilmente hacer la transición de un rpg posapocaliptico sci-fi a un city-builder de una forma muy orgánica pues ambas cosas van de la mano para avanzar en el agresivo entorno que no te dejara las cosas fáciles, lo cual me lleva a darle importancia a algo que ha sido el gancho final para atraparme por tantas horas y es su historia, su mundo orgánico y sus maravillosos eventos que cambian según la zona del mapa, me apasiona explorar tanto como me gusta recibir visitas en mi ciudad y repeler raids, mantiene el interés en seguir avanzando para hacerte mas fuerte y tomar venganza a quienes solo buscan verte perecer.

Totalmente recomendado si te gusta la gestión de recursos, los citybuilder y las narrativas emergentes, para mi uno de mis videojuegos favoritos que se que cada cierto retomare para jugar de nuevo y empezar siempre una nueva historia.

143757614.review:
In the desolate aftermath of an apocalyptic event that shattered the world, Atritiusoinus was born into a life of hardship and despair. The land was a wasteland, where the remnants of civilization clung to survival amidst the ruins of what once was. Born to parents who had known nothing but suffering and struggle, Atritiusoinus was destined to carve his own path in this unforgiving world.

Atritiusoinus had been a slave in his early years, shackled by the chains of oppression, forced to toil under the rule of a brutal warlord known as The Phoenix. But as time passed, a spark of defiance ignited within him. Atritiusoinus saw others around him, those who had managed to break free from their chains, eking out a dangerous existence as thieves and outlaws. He yearned for his own taste of freedom, no matter the cost.

One fateful night, Atritiusoinus managed to escape from The Phoenix's grasp, slipping through the shadows like a phantom. He knew the wasteland like the back of his hand, having observed it while toiling away in the warlord's encampment. His newfound freedom fueled a desire for revenge against the tyrant who had held him captive for so long.

With a small band of like-minded individuals, Atritiusoinus set out on a path of crime and rebellion. They became skilled scavengers, plundering the remnants of the old world for valuable artifacts and supplies. They learned to navigate the treacherous landscape, avoiding mutant creatures and rival factions that sought to claim their spoils. Atritiusoinus quickly became a charismatic leader, inspiring loyalty and courage in his comrades.

As their reputation grew, Atritiusoinus and his crew began to challenge The Phoenix's rule directly. They launched daring raids on his outposts, disrupting his operations and striking fear into his heart. Atritiusoinus used his knowledge of the terrain to outwit The Phoenix's enforcers, leading them into traps and ambushes.

But the life of crime was not without its sacrifices. Atritiusoinus faced moral dilemmas and internal conflicts. He saw the impact of his actions on the innocent survivors caught in the crossfire between his band and The Phoenix's forces. The wasteland had turned him into a hardened outlaw, but he still held a glimmer of compassion within him.

Amidst the chaos and danger, Atritiusoinus forged unlikely alliances. He encountered a skilled gunner named Truth, who had her own vendetta against The Phoenix. The two formed a bond born of shared goals and mutual respect. Together, they hatched a plan to bring down the warlord once and for all.

Their plan was audacious and dangerous, requiring every ounce of their cunning and bravery. Atritiusoinus and Truth orchestrated a massive uprising, rallying the oppressed survivors across the wasteland to stand against The Phoenix's tyranny. The final battle was a fierce and brutal struggle, with lives lost on both sides.

In the end, Atritiusoinus faced The Phoenix in a one-on-one confrontation that would determine the fate of the wasteland. It was a grueling battle of wills and strength, with Atritiusoinus tapping into reserves of determination he never knew he had. In a climactic moment, he emerged victorious, ending The Phoenix's reign of terror and bringing a semblance of justice to the shattered world.

With The Phoenix defeated, Atritiusoinus faced a new challenge: rebuilding and restoring hope to the wasteland. He and Truth, now his partner, worked tirelessly to establish a semblance of order, forming alliances with other factions and providing aid to those in need. Atritiusoinus had come a long way from his days as a slave, transforming from a symbol of defiance to a beacon of hope in a world desperately seeking redemption.

And so, in the midst of a desolate wasteland, Atritiusoinus's life of crime and rebellion evolved into a noble quest to bring light to the darkness, proving that even in the bleakest of times, the human spirit could rise above and forge a new future.

And then he got killed by bonedogs 
0/10

143431644.review:
Kenshi is The Sims meets Skyrim.
     It is The Sims for the players ability to create characters that you must manage in order to have them properly live a healthy life.
     And it is Skyrim for it's fantastical open world and freedom of what your can do, but Kenshi surpasses Skyrim in its freedom, there is no great threat you must stop, there is no war you must fight in, those things are there in Kenshi, but you have more freedom over it. You can claim bounties for cash, or become the bounty and destroy all of those who stand in your way.
     There's plenty of battles in Kenshi between the factions, and you may partake in them, but you can also start wars, rebel against powerful leaders and take their throne.
     But not everyone is up for the task of starting a rebellion, and you don't have to, you can just be a farmer who grows crops to trade in for cash so they can eat, or a miner who sells ore to the local populous. The possibilities are quite possibly endless, if you can pull it off.
     Even if you're a little tired of getting your ass kicked by starter game bandits, you can always get mods that make you start out with maxed out stats and OP gear. Kenshi truly has something for everyone.
     Sure, it is a little hard to pick up for beginners, but everyone's looked up a tutorial on youtube some time or another.
